summary: This is a discovery letter from the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York to the defense counsel for Ghislaine Maxwell, providing an index of materials disclosed pursuant to Rule 16 and requesting reciprocal discovery. It outlines the government's discovery obligations and policies regarding plea offers and sentencing reductions.

events.title: Discovery Disclosure in Maxwell Case
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office formally provides discovery materials to Ghislaine Maxwell's defense team, including a vast index of records.

events.title: Protective Order Issued
events.description: A protective order was entered in the case, governing the handling of confidential discovery materials.

keyFacts: The document is a formal discovery letter in the criminal case United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell (20 Cr. 330), indicating active pre-trial proceedings in August 2020.

The discovery index references a massive volume of materials (over 12,800 items) including search warrants, immigration/travel records for Epstein and Maxwell, financial records from numerous banks, flight manifests, and communications data.

Specific records listed include those from Epstein's estate executors (Darren Indyke and Richard Kahn) and flight manifests from pilots David Rodgers and Lawrence Visoki, highlighting the financial and travel networks under investigation.

The government outlines its policy to oppose a sentencing reduction for acceptance of responsibility if a guilty plea is not entered six weeks prior to trial or before the provision of Jencks Act (3500) material.
The letter explicitly states that no plea offer is effective unless made in writing and signed by authorized representatives of the U.S. Attorney's Office, formalizing the plea negotiation process.
